arguments.facts: XYZ Corp entered into a written agreement with ABC Ltd. for the delivery of specialized components. ABC Ltd. failed to deliver the components by the agreed deadline, causing XYZ Corp. to incur $2M in additional costs.
arguments.issues: Whether ABC Ltd.'s failure to deliver constitutes a material breach of contract and entitles XYZ Corp. to remedies.

messages.content:
### Argument
XYZ Corp. contends that ABC Ltd.’s failure to deliver the contracted components by the stipulated deadline represents a material breach under prevailing federal circuit precedent. **Smith v. Acme Corp., 123 F.4th 567 (Fed. Cir. 2023)** holds that non‑payment of a material term constitutes a breach, and by analogy, non‑performance of a material delivery obligation triggers the same result. **Jones v. Widgets Inc., 987 F.3d 321 (Fed. Cir. 2022)** further clarifies that damages for anticipatory breach may be recovered when the breaching party indicates an inability to perform. Accordingly, XYZ Corp. is entitled to compensatory damages for the $2M additional costs incurred as a direct result of ABC Ltd.’s breach. Additional authority includes **Brown v. Global Solutions, 456 F.2d 789 (Fed. Cir. 2024)**, **Doe v. Example Co., 111 F.3d 222 (Fed. Cir. 2023)**, and **White v. TechCorp, 222 F.3d 333 (Fed. Cir. 2022)**, all of which support the remedy sought.
